desc: ARID2 encodes a subunit in the Polybromo-associated BRG1-associated factor (PBAF) complex, a subtype of the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complexes. PBAF complex facilitates nuclear receptor-mediated, ligand-dependent transcriptional activation by modulating chromatin structure to make DNA more accessible to transcription factors (PMID: 19234488, 11780067) and ARID2 is thought to confer specificity to the complex (PMID:15985610). The ARID2 protein contains a conserved N-terminal AT-rich DNA interaction domain, a Regulatory Factor X (RFX) DNA-binding domain, a proline and glutamine-rich domain, and two C-terminal zinc-finger motifs, which can bind to DNA, RNA and proteins (PMID:22095441). Most ARID2 mutations found in tumors are inactivating, suggesting ARID2 is a tumor suppressor gene. It is most commonly found in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) (18.2% of cases), where ARID2 mutations often lead to an inactive, truncated protein (PMID: 21822264). In HCC, ARID2 stop mutations and TP53 mutations were mutually exclusive (PMID: 21822264). ARID2 mutations are also found in melanoma and non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), each at a rate of ~5% (PMID: 23047306, 22817889). For melanoma and NSCLC, missense mutations are associated with loss of heterozygosity (LOH) (PMID: 23047306).

articles/3/title: ARID2: a new tumor suppressor gene in hepatocellular carcinoma.
articles/4/title: PBAF chromatin-remodeling complex requires a novel specificity subunit, BAF200, to regulate expression of selective interferon-responsive genes.
articles/5/title: A landscape of driver mutations in melanoma.
articles/6/title: Inactivating mutations of the chromatin remodeling gene ARID2 in hepatocellular carcinoma.

desc: ARID2, a tumor suppressor involved in transcriptional regulation, is mutated in a diverse range of cancers.
